title: Lesson 15: Cell Culture Techniques and Applications
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding cell culture requirements, primary cultures vs cell lines, and applications in medical research including the HeLa cell story.
learningIntentions: Students can describe the basic requirements for cell culture (sterile conditions, appropriate temperature, nutrients, gas exchange).
Students can distinguish between primary cell cultures (from tissue) and cell lines (immortalised).
Students can outline the uses of cell culture in research and medicine (drug testing, vaccine production, toxicity testing).

engagementHook.title: The Laboratory Patient
engagementHook.content: 'Before a new drug touches a human, it meets a plastic dish containing living cells. These cells are the first 'patients' in clinical trials. Growing them is an art—too cold, they die; one bacterium, they die; wrong pH, they die. Today we explore the technology that allows us to grow life in a dish and why it revolutionised medicine.'

keyConcepts.definition: Growing cells outside the organism (in vitro) under controlled conditions.

Sterile environment (prevent bacterial/fungal contamination), 37°C (mammalian), CO₂ incubator (maintains pH via bicarbonate buffer), nutrient medium (amino acids, glucose, vitamins, serum with growth factors).
Cells taken directly from tissue (e.g., skin biopsy); limited divisions (Hayflick limit—senescence after ~50 divisions); genetically normal.
Immortalised cells (cancer cells like HeLa, or genetically modified) that divide indefinitely; easier to maintain but may differ genetically from original tissue.

Drug testing (cytotoxicity), vaccine production (growing viruses in cells), cancer research, production of therapeutic proteins (monoclonal antibodies), toxicity testing (cosmetics/chemicals—reduces animal testing).

misconceptions.misconception: Cell culture is like keeping a plant in a jar
misconceptions.correction: Much more complex—requires sterile technique, specific gases, constant temperature; cells are fragile outside body.
Primary cells senesce (age and stop dividing); only transformed/cancer cell lines are immortal.

misconceptions.misconception: Cell culture is only for growing cancer
misconceptions.correction: Used for normal cells (stem cells, skin grafts) and many non-cancer applications (vaccines).

contentSections.title: The Culture Environment
contentSections.content: Sterile hood (HEPA filtered air), 37°C incubator, 5% CO₂ (maintains pH ~7.4 in medium with bicarbonate), medium with nutrients and fetal bovine serum (growth factors). Aseptic technique (washing hands, flaming instruments, working near flame).
contentSections.example: COVID-19 vaccine development—viruses grown in cell cultures (Vero cells) to produce vaccine doses.

items: Closer to in vivo conditions; limited supply
Easy to maintain; unlimited supply for research

contentSections.title: HeLa Cells and Ethics
contentSections.content: Henrietta Lacks' cervical cancer cells (1951) became first immortal cell line; used for polio vaccine, cancer research, gene mapping. Raised issues of consent and commercialisation (not consented, family not compensated for decades).
contentSections.example: Importance of ethical consent in cell culture; cells can outlive donor and be shipped worldwide.

multipleChoice.question: Which condition is essential for maintaining the correct pH in mammalian cell culture?
multipleChoice.rationale: CO₂ for pH control. Maintains bicarbonate buffer at physiological pH ~7.4.

multipleChoice.question: Primary cell cultures differ from continuous cell lines in that primary cultures:
options: Have a limited lifespan/senesce after several divisions
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Have a limited lifespan/senesce after several divisions
multipleChoice.rationale: Hayflick limit concept. Primary cells undergo ~50 divisions then senesce; cell lines are immortal.

multipleChoice.question: Cell culture is used in medical research for all of the following EXCEPT:
multipleChoice.rationale: Definition of in vitro applications. Surgery is clinical, not laboratory cell culture.

shortAnswer.question: Outline three conditions that must be maintained when culturing animal cells in vitro. (3 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Sterile/aseptic conditions (to prevent bacterial/fungal contamination)
1 mark: Appropriate temperature (37°C for mammalian cells/maintains enzyme function)
1 mark: Correct gas atmosphere (5% CO₂ to maintain pH) OR nutrient medium (growth factors, amino acids)
shortAnswer.commonError: Mentioning 'light' (not needed for animal cells) or 'soil' (plant confusion).

shortAnswer.question: Distinguish between primary cell cultures and continuous cell lines. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Primary cells are derived directly from tissue and have a limited lifespan/number of divisions; cell lines are immortalised/can divide indefinitely
1 mark: Primary cells are usually genetically normal (diploid); cell lines may be genetically abnormal/transformed (cancerous)
shortAnswer.commonError: Stating primary cells come from 'primary school' or confusing with 'primates.'

definitions: Cell culture requires sterile technique, 37°C, 5% CO₂ (for pH), and nutrient medium.
Primary cells: From tissue directly, limited divisions, genetically normal.
Cell lines: Immortal/continuous, divide indefinitely, may be cancerous.
Uses: Drug testing, vaccine production, toxicity testing, cancer research.
HeLa cells: First immortal human cell line (ethical issues of consent).
keyPoints: Sterile technique essential - bacteria outcompete cells
CO₂ maintains pH via bicarbonate buffer
diagrams: Primary cells vs cell lines comparison

shortAnswer: Three essential conditions for culturing animal cells in vitro are: (1) Sterile or aseptic conditions must be maintained to prevent contamination by bacteria or fungi, which would outcompete and kill the animal cells; (2) The temperature must be maintained at 37°C for mammalian cells, as this is the optimal temperature for enzyme function and cellular processes; (3) A 5% CO₂ atmosphere is required to maintain the correct pH (approximately 7.4) of the culture medium through the bicarbonate buffer system. Additionally, a nutrient medium containing amino acids, glucose, vitamins, and growth factors (often from fetal bovine serum) is essential for cell survival and proliferation.

Primary cell cultures are derived directly from living tissue and consist of cells that have a limited lifespan, typically undergoing approximately 50 divisions (the Hayflick limit) before entering senescence (aging and stopping division). These cells are usually genetically normal (diploid) and maintain characteristics closer to cells in the living organism. In contrast, continuous cell lines are immortalised cells that have been transformed (often derived from cancer tissue or genetically modified) and can divide indefinitely in culture. While easier to maintain and providing unlimited supply for research, cell lines may be genetically abnormal (aneuploid or mutated) and may not accurately represent normal cell behaviour.
